3c336be68513.title: I was leaning toward Harden as the MVP a for the last month, however, upon inspection of what…

paragraphs.text: I was leaning toward Harden as the MVP a for the last month, however, upon inspection of what Westbrook has done in the last week, its undeniable. He has sparked one of the greatest seasons anyone has ever had. The fact that he has sustained such greatness over (potentially) 82 games is a feat untouched. This is ‘06 Kobe on Steroids and Kobe was robbed of the award. We should never let that happen again.
paragraphs.name: 11b2

paragraphs.text: I vote for Harden. I agree with the argument that he changed his game to fit his teammates and a new philosophy to vastly improve the Rockets. Westbrook is amazing, but triple doubles aren’t as impressive when you consider the talent around him. I think Westbrook will win, but I think it’s because of the Durant factor and people who are too easily dazzled.
paragraphs.name: f1f6

4cedd4a9eeb0.title: Without Harden, the Rockets would be a bad team.

paragraphs.text: Without Harden, the Rockets would be a bad team. Without Westbrook, the Thunder would be demoted to the D-League. Westbrook should win MVP, just like 2006 Kobe should have won MVP.
paragraphs.name: d093

paragraphs.text: Oh and I almost forgot that Harden broke his own turn over record from last year. How the F can you be the MVP if that’s the record you break?

136eced18ab.bio: ...you can't tell a heart when to start, how to beat...
136eced18ab.name: Eric Hofmann

paragraphs.text: All this more or less confirms what we know anecdotally: the Rockets have a team built perfectly around Harden’s talents; the Thunder have a team built around Westbrook’s insistence on doing everything. We’ve set the stage for a compelling four-man finish, but if this still feels like a two-man race to you, it’s because Westbrook and Harden most clearly represent the two most basic schools of thought when it comes to determining the meaning of “most valuable.” Is it fair to penalize a player for being on a team complementary to his talents? Is it fair to champion a player whose extraordinary effort still only amounts to being the best option on a middling team? Every year, MVP voters grapple with the significance of individual and collective success and how one informs the other — and every year, the rationale changes. That there is no hardline answer is both beautiful and frustrating. Because all we want is for sports to align with how we see the world. (My theoretical vote would go to Harden. Disagree? Let’s be friends.)
paragraphs.name: 2b9b

We’ve set the stage for a compelling four-man finish, but if this still feels like a two-man race to you, it’s because Westbrook and Harden most clearly represent the two most basic schools of thought when it comes to determining the meaning of “most valuable.” Is it fair to penalize a player for being on a team complementary to his talents? Is it fair to champion a player whose extraordinary effort still only amounts to being the best option on a middling team? Every year, MVP voters grapple with the significance of individual and collective success and how one informs the other — and every year, the rationale changes. That there is no hardline answer is both beautiful and frustrating. Because all we want is for sports to align with how we see the world. (My theoretical vote would go to Harden. Disagree? Let’s be friends.)
paragraphs.name: 2b9b
